text: The text of mezuzot is not written on parchment made of skins of unclean (i.e. non-kosher) domestic animals or unclean wild animals, but it is written on parchment made from skins of dead (i.e. not slaughtered in a way fit for eating) or sick (in a way that makes them unfit for eating) kosher animals. And we are not concerned that perhaps the skins were pierced at the animal’s heart.
One must place the same size margin on all sides, as Rabbi Shimon Ben Elazar said.

If the mezuzah parchment was perforated in the location of the writing, it is invalid; if in an empty space, it is valid. If one wrote the letter vavs as zayins, zayins as vavs, regular letters as final ones, final ones as regular ones, the paragraph separators petucha as setuma, setuma as petucha, or if he mixed up its other letters or wrote them in Paleo-Hebrew script, it is invalid.

A storehouse for hay, a woodshed, and a general storehouse are exempt from the requirement of mezuzah. A cattle barn is exempt. If women make use of it to adorn it, it is obligated, i.e. a mezuzah is required at its entrance. Cone-shaped huts, watchtowers, field sheds, and tanneries are exempt from mezuzah.
A bathhouse is exempt from mezuzah. If there is a dwelling in it that opens outside this opening is obligated.

A doorway in a corner only has one doorpost. A doorway made with boards such that there is no clear doorpost, the wall just ends, only has one doorpost. Such cases require a mezuzah. Rabbi Eliezer Ben Yaakov exempts them.

An arched gateway is exempted from a mezuzah. Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda obligate it, but they all agree that if the gateway is a straight wall below for at least ten tefachim and the arch is above that, then the arch requires a mezuzah.

Gates of a city and gates of streets require a mezuzah. Gates of courtyards are exempt. The chambers in the Temple were exempt from mezuzah. The chamber that was called Beit HaParvah, which was the High Priest’s residence seven days a year, and Sukkot of potters require mezuzot. Rabbi Yossi exempts them.
The mezuzah is written on a scroll that is affixed on the right side at the entrance from the market to a gatehouse and at the exit from the courtyard to the gatehouse.

If one has a garden that has doorposts from the courtyard, he affixes a mezuzah on the right in the direction of exiting the garden into the courtyard. And if there is a gatehouse between the garden and the courtyard he affixes mezuzot entering the gatehouse in both directions.

Regarding a small room similar to a gatehouse that serves as an entrance to a large room, we affix the mezuzah on the right in order of size from small to large, unlike a gatehouse. If all the doorways to the room are frequently used, one places a mezuzah on all of them.

Regarding two rooms next to each other with a doorway between them we affix the mezuzah on the right side as one enters further inside the house, i.e. from the outer room to the inner room. Rabbi Yehuda says: if there is a movable ladder to all four sides we affix mezuzot to them.

Regarding an entrance from the roof into the house, one affixes a mezuzah in the direction of the house coming from the roof. Rabbi Nosson bRabi Yossi says there are differing opinions regarding whether an entrance from the roof needs a mezuzah. Beit Shammai requires one while Beit Hillel exempts it.
Regarding a permanent sukkah inside the roof, one affixes a mezuzah on the right in the direction exiting from the sukkah to the roof. Rabbi Yossi says entering from the roof to the sukkah.

Regarding a portico inside the house attached to rooms from which there is no exit to anywhere else except these rooms, thus making it an “inner” room, one affixes a mezuzah on the right in the direction exiting from the portico into the houses. Rabbi Yossi says entering from the houses to the portico.
title: Tractate Mezuzah
